Research article Synergistic effect of single atoms and clusters on boosting activity of TiO2-supported Pd catalysts towards total furfural hydrogenation Jin Gu Investigation a b Hao Zhang Formal analysis a ⁎ 1 Miao Guo Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Methodology Funding acquisition Data curation Conceptualization b ⁎ Yanming Hu Writing – review & editing b a College of Food Science and Engineering, National Engineering Research Center of Wheat and Corn Further Processing, Jilin Agricultural University, Changchun 130118, People's Republic of China College of Food Science and Engineering National Engineering Research Center of Wheat and Corn Further Processing Jilin Agricultural University Changchun 130118 People's Republic of China College of Food Science and Engineering, National Engineering Research Center of Wheat and Corn Further Processing, Jilin Agricultural University, Changchun 130118, People's Republic of China b Division of Energy Materials, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, People's Republic of China Division of Energy Materials Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian 116023 People's Republic of China Division of Energy Materials, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, People's Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 ORCID 000-0002-8582-8493. Graphical abstract Total furfural (FAL) hydrogenation to the industrially valuable tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFOL) involves the cascade hydrogenation of the formyl and furanic groups. However, supported metal catalysts are generally confronted with low activity, especially under mild conditions. Herein, we present a highly active Pd catalyst supported on TiO2 with a Pd loading of 0.2 wt% (0.2Pd/TiO2) for the efficient one-pot conversion of FAL to THFOL. Under mild conditions (25 °C, 60 bar H2), 0.2Pd/TiO2 achieves 90 % FAL conversion and 96 % selectivity to THFOL, outperforming the conventional high-Pd-content catalysts (e.g. 5 wt%Pd/TiO2) and most reported catalysts. Detailed characterization and kinetic investigations reveal that the exceptional performance stems from the synergistic interplay between Pd single atoms and nanoclusters on the 0.2Pd/TiO2 catalyst. Furthermore, kinetic studies highlight the crucial role of H2O in promoting the desired reaction pathway. Impressively, 0.2Pd/TiO2 demonstrates excellent stability, the activity and selectivity remain nearly identical even over seven consecutive reaction cycles. Moreover, the catalyst exhibits broad applicability, effectively hydrogenating various furanic compounds to the corresponding saturated products. This study provides key insights into the rational design of highly efficient and selective catalysts for tandem hydrogenation reactions. Keywords Furfural Hydrogenation Pd TiO2 Tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The growing concerns over limited fossil fuel resources and environmental impacts have intensified the focus on biorefinery, a process that converts biomass into value-added products [1–5]. Among the chemicals derived from biomass, furfural (FAL) produced through dehydration of sugars is particularly significant as a platform chemical in biorefinery [6,7]. Due to its chemically active carbonyl and furan groups, FAL can be transformed into various biofuels and chemical intermediates through the processes such as hydrogenation, decarboxylation, hydrogenolysis, and selective ring opening [8,9]. Among these products, tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFOL), the fully hydrogenated product of FAL, can serve as a green solvent used in printer inks and has found agricultural applications due to its degradability as well as less toxic and more stable properties, compared to the unsaturated furan compounds [10]. Notably, THFOL can also be converted into valuable straight-chain 1,5-pentanediol through hydrogenolysis [11]. Traditionally, THFOL is produced via a two-step hydrogenation process—FAL to FOL, and then to THFOL—using a cascade catalysis strategy. However, the harsh conditions employed in this process usually result in coke deposition and catalyst deactivation due to the FOL polymerization [12]. Consequently, there is increasing interest in one-pot total FAL hydrogenation to produce THFOL over supported metal nanoparticles (NPs), as this method reduces product separation/purification steps and lowers energy consumption [13,14]. Nevertheless, development of efficient metal catalysts for this transformation remains challenging, especially under mild conditions. The FAL hydrogenation on metal surfaces is particularly intricate (Scheme 1 ); the product selectivity is strongly influenced by the catalyst structure and reaction parameters [15]. For instance, the side reactions like C–O hydrogenolysis to 2-methylfuran, decarbonylation to furan, and rearrangement to levulinic acid can occur simultaneously. To achieve efficient total FAL hydrogenation to THFOL, it requires a catalytic system that can selectively hydrogenate CC or CO bonds while suppressing alternative pathways such as hydrogenolysis. The adsorption configuration of FAL on metal surfaces, particularly on palladium (Pd), is complex, and the multiple binding modes significantly impact the product selectivity [16–18]. Previous studies have demonstrated that the most stable adsorption configuration involves the furan ring and CO group lying parallel to the surface [15,18]. This configuration tends to yield FOL as the initial hydrogenation product due to the relatively easy hydrogenation of the CO group. However, achieving optimal catalytic performance for subsequent FOL hydrogenation on a specific metal surface is challenging due to the scaling relationship in heterogeneous catalysis [19,20], which explains the usually observed low catalytic efficiency of NPs catalysed total FAL hydrogenation in the literatures. Designing catalyst active site structures emerges as key to enhancing the overall efficiency of cascade multi-step reactions like total FAL hydrogenation [21,22]. Dual- or multi-site catalysts, for example, have been employed to balance the trade-off between activity and selectivity. These catalysts utilize different active sites to independently regulate the adsorption and activation of different reactants. For instance, recent studies have shown that combining Pd single-atom catalysts (SACs) with Pd NPs could enhance the capabilities for activation of CO groups and dissociation of H2, thereby leading to highly efficient hydrogenation of ketones and aldehydes to alcohols at room temperature [23]. The spatially separated PdRu dual metal catalyst has shown promise in cascade hydrogenation reactions by using different metals for distinct reaction steps and facilitating molecular transfer through nanochannels [24]. Another effective approach is to increase the number of active sites available for enhancing the catalytic performance. For the oxide-supported metal NPs, the formation of active sites at the metal/metal oxide interface is particularly important, as these sites are often responsible for hydrogenation activity [25–27]. Recently, Margherita Macino and colleagues reported that more peripheral sites at the Pt/TiO2 interface could be created by tailoring the metal loading and preparation parameters and consequently enhance the selectivity in the selective hydrogenation of 3-nitrostyrene [28]. In addition to catalyst structure, FAL hydrogenation is also strongly influenced by the solvent utilized, and altering the solvent can change the distribution of major products [29]. Recent research showed that polar protic solvents could enhance catalytic activity but led to the formation of unwanted by-products like acetyl and ester adducts [30]. Conversely, although the formation of these by-products could be suppressed through the utilization of some non-polar solvents, the reaction rate was significantly reduced [31]. Resasco and coworkers [32] demonstrated that H2O could participate in the rate-determining step (RDS) of FAL hydrogenation by providing an additional channel for hydrogenation of the CO group and potentially influencing the overall reaction mechanism. The promotion effect of H2O in FAL hydrogenation is probably related to the weak interaction between the substrate and solvent (e.g. forming a hydrogen bond with CO group) [33] and the altered H2 dissociation ability on the metal surface [34]. Among the various catalysts explored for total FAL hydrogenation, supported Pd catalysts have attracted the most attention due to their superior intrinsic activity for both the furan ring and aromatic CO group [14,15,18,32]. However, to realize high yields of THFOL typically requires harsh conditions, large amounts of catalyst, or both. In this study, we develop a highly active TiO2-supported Pd catalyst for total FAL hydrogenation. With a low Pd loading of 0.2 wt% (denoted as 0.2Pd/TiO2), this catalyst surpasses the performance of the control catalyst with a higher Pd content (5Pd/TiO2) and most of the catalysts reported in the literature. As revealed by systematic characterizations, the high activity and selectivity of 0.2Pd/TiO2 is attributed to the synergistic effect of Pd SACs and Pd nanoclusters (NCs). Moreover, kinetic studies of FAL hydrogenation on 0.2Pd/TiO2 and 5Pd/TiO2 demonstrated the important role of H2O in the reaction. The 0.2Pd/TiO2 catalyst also exhibits excellent catalytic stability and efficiency for the hydrogenation of other furanic compounds. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All chemicals were used as received without further purification. TiO2 (rutile, 25 nm) and n-tetradecane were obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., Ltd. Na2PdCl4 (36.4 wt% Pd) was purchased from Beijing Innochem Co., Ltd. Furfural (FAL), furfuryl alcohol (FOL), and tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFOL) were obtained from TCI chemicals, Shanghai. Other organic chemicals, CeO2, SiO2, Fe3O4, MgO, Al2O3, and ZnO were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of Pd/TiO2 Pd/TiO2 was prepared by a typical incipient wetness impregnation method. Specifically, 2.0 g of TiO2 was dispersed in 6.0 mL of deionized water, and then the desired amount of Na2PdCl4 (1.0 g/mL) was added. After stirring for 12 h at room temperature, the reaction mixture was evaporated by rotary evaporation to remove the solvent. After drying at 110 °C for 2 h, the powder product was reduced at 200 °C for 2 h in a H2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1 (H2 flow: 20 mL min−1). The obtained catalyst was designated as xPd/TiO2, where x is the Pd content. Here, x% = 0.1 %, 0.2 %, 0.5 %, 2 %, or 5 %. The procedure for the synthesis of other oxides supported Pd NPs with Pd loading of 0.2 % was similar to 0.2Pd/TiO2 except for the corresponding oxides used. The obtained catalyst was denoted as Pd/MOx, where MOx is CeO2, SiO2, Fe3O4, MgO, Al2O3, or ZnO. 2.3 General procedure for catalytic hydrogenation FAL hydrogenation was performed in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a pressure gauge, magnetic stirrer, and an electric temperature controller. Typically, a desired amount of catalyst (0.2Pd/TiO2, 53 mg) was placed in a 4 mL reaction tube, followed by the addition of FAL (1.0 mmol) and 2.0 mL of solvent. The reaction tube was then loaded into the reactor. After the reactor was purged six times with H2, the final pressure was adjusted to 20 bar, and the temperature was raised to 30 °C with vigorous stirring. After the reaction, the reaction filtrate was collected, diluted with EtOH, and analyzed by an Agilent 8890 GC equipped with an Agilent J&W GC HP–5 capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm). Conversion and selectivity were determined using n-tetradecane as the internal standard, and the carbon balance for all reactions was >85 %. In the binary solvent of EtOH and H2O, the solvent was abbreviated as x%EtOH in the following discussion, where x is the volume fraction of EtOH. The apparent turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated using the initial conversion (∼15 %) in hydrogenation reactions. The apparent TOF (normalized by total metal content) and GC yield of product is defined as follows: ApparentTOF ( h - 1 ) = m m o l o f r e a c t a n t r e a c t e d ( m m o l o f m e t a l ) ( r e a c t i o n t i m e / h ) G C Y i e l d % = m m o l o f p r o d u c t i o b t a i n e d m m o l o f r e a c t a n t r e a c t e d × 100 % To ensure the collection of reliable kinetic data, a control experiment was carried out at different stirring rates, and the results showed that the reaction rate remained constant within the range of 500–1000 rpm. The reactions in this study were conducted at 700 rpm to avoid catalyst splashing. Furthermore, the elimination of mass transfer limitations in our three-phase stirred reactor can also be assessed using widely accepted criteria from a previous report [35], where both the gas–liquid and liquid–solid mass transfer ratios are less than 0.1 (calculations see Supporting Information). For the activation energy measurement, the reaction was performed with 20 bar H2, 1.0 mmol FAL, 2.0 mL 55 %EtOH, with S/C = 500 and 1000 for 5Pd/TiO2 and 0.2Pd/TiO2, respectively. Reaction temperature ranged from 25 to 55 °C. 2.4 Reusability of the Pd/TiO2 To examine the reusability of the Pd/TiO2 catalyst, the liquid was decanted after centrifugation of the reaction mixture. The residual catalyst was thoroughly washed with EtOH, dried at 80 °C for 2 h, and used directly for the next run. 2.5 Characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a HITACHI HT7700 at an acceleration voltage of 100 kV. High-resolution scanning electron microscopy (HRSEM) was performed using a HITACHI S5500 apparatus operating at an acceleration voltage of 1–30 kV. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images, high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images, and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) of 0.2Pd/TiO2 were acquired using a JEM-ARM200F. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on an Empyrean power diffraction system with Cu-Kα radiation operated at 40 kV and 200 mA. The 2θ angle was scanned in the range of 10–80°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were collected using the ESCALAB 250Xi equipped with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (hλ = 1486.6 eV). The binding energy scales were calibrated using the C 1s peak at a binding energy of 284.8 eV. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) analysis was used to quantify Pd leaching during the catalyst synthesis and hydrogenation reactions. The analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 7300 DV equipment. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of CO adsorption was performed on an infrared spectrophotometer VERTEX 80 V equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector. IR spectra were recorded in the range between 600 and 4000 cm−1 with a spectral resolution of 4 cm−1. Prior to measurements, about 30 mg of catalyst was reduced in a H2/Ar flow (10 mL min−1) at 200 °C for 1 h. After that, the system was cooled to 30 °C in an Ar flow (10 mL min−1), followed by purging with Ar flow at the same temperature for 30 min. A spectrum was taken and used as the background for the following adsorption experiments. The Ar flow was then switched to a pure CO flow (10 mL min−1) until saturated adsorption was achieved. CO adsorption experiments were carried out sequentially on a single sample. Gas–phase CO spectra were collected at the same pressure and subtracted from the corresponding sample spectra. H2-D2 exchange experiments were conducted on the AutoChem II-DSMS apparatus. The reactions were carried out in a flow quartz reactor at 30 °C. The formation rate of HD was measured by mass signal intensity (ion current). Before the test, the catalysts (0.02 mg Pd) were heated in H2 (10 % in Ar, 30 mL min−1) at 200 °C for 60 min. After cooling to room temperature, a mixture of D2 (20 mL min−1) and H2 was passed through the sample. Products (HD, H2, and D2) were analyzed with an online mass spectrometer (GAM200, InProcess Instruments). The mass/charge ratio (m/z) values used were 2 for H2, 4 for D2, and 3 for HD. The background HD exchanges from the corresponding support were deducted from the results. H2-TPD and H2-TPR were conducted using an Autochem II 2920 chemisorption instrument. For H2-TPD, ∼100 mg of catalyst sample was placed in a U-type quartz tube and heated to 200 °C for 60 min in H2 (10 % in Ar, 30 mL min−1) to remove adsorbed species from catalyst surface. When the sample was cooled down to −50 °C, the flow was switched to Ar (30 mL min−1) for 60 min. The sample was then heated to 600 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1 in Ar flow and the TPD profiles were recorded simultaneously. For H2-TPR, the experiment procedure was identical to H2-TPD, except that Ar (30 mL min−1) was used to remove adsorbed species from catalyst surface in the pretreatment procedure and after cooling the temperature to −50 °C, the sample was directly heated to 600 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1 under H2 flow (10 vol% in Ar, 30 mL min−1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst screening The catalytic performance of supported Pd catalysts on various metal oxides (Pd/MOx) was initially evaluated for FAL hydrogenation. The catalysts were prepared using a typical incipient wetness impregnation method, with hydrogen as the reductant, and the Pd loading was fixed at 0.2 wt% for all Pd/MOx samples. Under the reaction conditions of 30 °C, 10 bar H2, and a substrate-to-catalyst molar ratio (S/C) of 645, the FAL conversions catalyzed by Pd/TiO2, Pd/Fe3O4, and Pd/CeO2, were 85 %, 55 %, and 21 %, respectively (Fig. 1 a). The main products were FOL and THFOL, with by-products including acetals, 2-methylfuran, and trace amounts of ring-opening compounds. Minimal FAL conversion was observed for Pd NPs supported on SiO2, MgO, Al2O3, and ZnO. Notably, just the two catalysts Pd/TiO2 and Pd/CeO2 afforded THFOL, and the former gave a significantly higher yield (74 % vs. 11 %). Among the investigated Pd catalysts, Pd/TiO2 demonstrated the highest activity and THFOL yield, underscoring the unique ability of TiO2 to support Pd for total FAL hydrogenation. The effects of reduction temperature and Pd content of Pd/TiO2 were further investigated, and the results are summarized in Fig. 1b and c. As the reduction temperature increased from 80 to 200 °C, the FAL conversion increased from 68 % to 90 %. Further increasing the reduction temperature resulted in a rapid decrease in FAL conversion. The combined selectivity towards FOL and THFOL followed a similar trend, 0.2Pd/TiO2 reduced at 200 °C yielded the lowest formation of byproduct (3 % acetals). The characteristic volcanic curve observed in FAL hydrogenation as a function of reduction temperature may be related to both the Pd reduction degree and metal-support interaction between Pd and TiO2 [36]. On the other hand, the FAL conversion steadily increased as the Pd loading decreased from 5 % to 0.2 %. Meanwhile, the selectivity towards FOL and THFOL increased while the byproducts decreased. Pd/TiO2 with a Pd content of 0.2 wt% exhibited the highest FAL conversion and combined selectivity towards FOL and THFOL. Further decreasing the Pd content to 0.1 wt% resulted in a slightly lower THFOL yield, though a slightly higher FAL conversion was observed. Considering the high THFOL yield, 0.2Pd/TiO2 was used in the following investigation. Previous studies have demonstrated that the solvent utilized has a significant impact on the activity and selectivity of FAL hydrogenation [14,32]. Consequently, FAL hydrogenation was performed in various solvents, and the results are summarized in Table S1. The highest activity was observed in EtOH (26 %), followed by CH3COOH (14 %), acetone (11 %), EtOAc (10 %), toluene (10 %), and H2O (6 %). The highest activity in EtOH is likely related to the hydrogen-bond-promoted carbonyl activation [33]. Across all the solvents tested, the main side products were acetals and hydrogenolysis products. Notably, the FOL selectivity was significantly higher in H2O compared with other solvents (>99 %), suggesting that H2O plays an important role in the hydrogenation process. Given the excellent activity and selectivity of FAL hydrogenation in EtOH and H2O, the solvent effect were investigated using a binary solvent system of EtOH and H2O. The S/C ratio was adjusted to 300 to better reflect the catalytic performance. As depicted in Fig. 1d, the FAL conversion decreased monotonically with increasing the H2O content, while the combined selectivity towards FOL and THFOL steadily increased from 86 % to 99 % as the H2O content increased to 45 %. These results suggest that the presence of a certain amount of H2O in EtOH can efficiently suppress the side reactions. Further increasing H2O content to 75 % resulted in a slightly decreased selectivity towards FOL and THFOL (91 %). Although the promotion effect of H2O in hydrogenation is complicated, it is likely associated with the enhanced hydrogen dissociation ability on the Pd surface and/or the promotion of FAL activation through the easily formed hydrogen bonding with the polar solvent [14,32,33,37,38]. 0.2Pd/TiO2 exhibited an apparent TOF of 3060 h−1 for total FAL hydrogenation at 30 °C, 20 bar H2, and an S/C = 1000, in a mixture solvent of EtOH/H2O (55 %/45 %). However, complete FAL conversion was not achieved under these conditions. Generally, low temperature, high pressure, and low S/C are beneficial for the hydrogenation of polar unsaturated functional groups. To better compare the catalytic performance with the literature results, the reaction conditions were adjusted to 25 °C, 60 bar H2, and a S/C ratio of 150. Under these conditions, 0.2Pd/TiO2 achieved 90 % FAL conversion and 96 % selectivity to THFOL, with a gas chromatography (GC) yield of 86 %, implying it is the most active and selective solid catalyst reported to date for total FAL hydrogenation (Table S2). 3.2 Characterization of Pd/TiO2 To understand the high activity of 0.2Pd/TiO2 in total hydrogenation of FAL, 0.2Pd/TiO2 was characterized, along with 5Pd/TiO2 as a reference catalyst. As shown in Fig. S1a, 0.2Pd/TiO2 primarily consists of ellipsoidal/spherical particles with an average particle size of approximately 50 nm. The BET surface area of 0.2Pd/TiO2 is 32.8 m2/g, slightly higher than that of 5Pd/TiO2 (26.4 m2/g) (Table 1 ). The adsorption–desorption isotherms of BET results (Fig. S2) reveal only cumulative pores in these catalysts, consistent with the HRSEM observations. These results suggest that the Pd is located on the surface of TiO2, making it easily accessible to the reactants during catalysis. In the HAADF-STEM images of 0.2Pd/TiO2 (Fig. 2 a and b), the isolated bright dots are corresponding to the Pd single atoms (SACs, highlighted with red circles) along with several nanoclusters (NCs, highlighted with blue circles), confirming the presence of both Pd SACs and NCs within 0.2Pd/TiO2. We quantified the occurrences of Pd SACs and NCs by randomly assessing 100 Pd species. The ratio of NCs to SACs is approximately 1:4, indicating that the majority of Pd species on 0.2Pd/TiO2 exists as SACs. The HRTEM/TEM image reveals no obvious Pd NPs existed in 0.2Pd/TiO2 (Figs. 2c and S1b). Determined by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, Fig. 2d), 0.2Pd/TiO2 shows the homogeneous distribution of Pd atoms and NCs on the surface of TiO2. Notably, the Pd NCs, consisting of a specific number of Pd atoms, are predominantly arranged in a 2D structure on the TiO2 surface, suggesting that most of the Pd sites on 0.2Pd/TiO2 are fully exposed. Recent works have proved that this exposure is beneficial for catalysis [39,40]. CO chemisorption analysis shows that the Pd dispersion on 0.2Pd/TiO2 is 40.6 %, much higher than that on 5Pd/TiO2 (4.4 %, Table 1), further indicating the high level of exposed Pd on 0.2Pd/TiO2. The wide-angle XRD patterns of 0.2Pd/TiO2 (Fig. S3) only show diffraction peaks attributed to TiO2, confirming the high dispersion of Pd species on the TiO2 surface. In contrast, 5Pd/TiO2 displays distinct diffraction peaks corresponding to Pd, indicating the presence of Pd NPs. Using the Scherrer equation, the size of these Pd crystallites on 5Pd/TiO2 was calculated to be approximately 14.7 nm. These results highlight the clear difference in Pd species between 5Pd/TiO2 and 0.2Pd/TiO2. The surface structure of Pd/TiO2, which may influence the catalytic performance, was investigated using diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of CO adsorption. The C–O stretching frequency is particularly sensitive to change on the metal surface when CO is adsorbed. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the main adsorption peaks fall within the ranges of 2200–2000 cm−1 and 2000–1800 cm−1, corresponding to the linearly CO on Pd SACs/larger Pd ensembles and bridged CO adsorption on Pd for the oxide-supported Pd catalysts [41,42]. For 0.2Pd/TiO2, the vibration at 2083 cm−1 is attributed to CO molecules linearly adsorbed on single-atom Pd species (Pd⁰) (see Table S3 for the assignment of CO adsorbed on Pd SACs) [41]. The bands at 1968 and 1864 cm−1 correspond to CO adsorbed on bridge and hollow sites of Pd ensembles [43]. No vibrational peaks associated with CO adsorbed on Pdδ+ species (above 2100 cm−1) were observed, likely due to their easy removal by Ar flow. These results suggest the coexistence of Pd SACs and agglomerated Pd species on 0.2Pd/TiO2, which aligns with the HRTEM findings. In contrast, for 5Pd/TiO2, a relatively lower intensity vibration signal at 2090 cm−1, corresponding to CO adsorbed on Pd SACs or larger Pd ensembles, and higher intensity signals at 1986, 1925, and 1884 cm−1, attributed to bridge-bonded CO on Pd surfaces, indicate that agglomerated Pd is the predominant species on 5Pd/TiO2. Rough calculations suggest that the ratio of CO linearly on Pd0 to bridged adsorbed sites for 0.2Pd/TiO2 and 5Pd/TiO2 is 0.4 and 0.06, respectively, indicating fewer Pd-Pd structures on 0.2Pd/TiO2, consistent with the HRTEM results. Compared to 5Pd/TiO2, the signal corresponding to CO adsorbed on Pd SACs appears more quickly as a function of purging time (Fig. S4), further supporting that SACs are the dominant species on 0.2Pd/TiO2. The surface electronic structures of Pd/TiO2 catalysts were further investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). For 5Pd/TiO2, the peaks at 335.0 and 337.4 eV corresponding to Pd0 and Pd2+ states, respectively, were observed (Fig. 3b, Table 1). After deconvolution, the Pd0/Pd2+ ratio of 54.0/46.0 is typical for NPs, suggesting that 5Pd/TiO2 primarily consists of Pd NPs (Table 1). In contrast, for 0.2Pd/TiO2, a broad peak centered at 336.0 eV is detected. This binding energy (BE) lies between that of Pd0 and Pd2+, implying the presence of both Pd SACs and NCs. Generally, the presence of Ti3+-Ov states in TiO2 can anchor the metallic Pd cations, improving Pd dispersion and resulting in electron transfer between Pd and TiO2 [44]. The existence of Ti3+-Ov states was also confirmed by EPR spectroscopy, where a signal at g = 1.973, attributed to these states, was detected (Fig. S5) [45]. Notably, the 0.2Pd/TiO2 sample exhibited a significantly higher Ti3+ signal intensity, indicating that doping 0.2 wt% Pd into the TiO2 generates more surface defects. Additionally, deconvolution of the Ti 2p3/2 and O 1s shows that the Ti3+/chemisorbed oxygen species (OII) content follows the order: 0.2Pd/TiO2 > 5Pd/TiO2 > TiO2 (Fig. S6, Table S4), further suggesting 0.2Pd/TiO2 has more surface defects. These results are consistent with the EPR results. The relatively lower defect density on the surface of 5Pd/TiO2 may be due to its more agglomerated Pd NPs [46]. 0.2Pd/TiO2 and 5Pd/TiO2 contain different Pd species and the distinct coordination environments between the diverse Pd species and Ti3+-Ov states in the two catalysts lead to the different Pd electronic states observed in the XPS results. The effect of reduction temperature on the reducibility of the catalysts was investigated using H2-TPR measurements, and the results are shown in Fig. 3c. For 5Pd/TiO2, four positive peaks at 0.3, 320, 415, and 510 °C, and one negative peak at 80 °C were observed. The peak at 0.3 °C is attributed to the reduction of PdO and the formation of the PdH phase, while the negative peak at 80 °C is due to the decomposition of PdH [47]. The peaks at 320, 415, and 510 °C correspond to the surface reduction of TiO2. This above TPR results is typical for supported Pd NPs on TiO2 with high metal loading [46,47]. In contrast, for 0.2Pd/TiO2, only the PdO reduction peak at −3.8 °C and the TiO2 surface reduction peaks at 320 and 510 °C were observed. The slight shift to a lower temperature for the PdO reduction peak in 0.2Pd/TiO2 is consistent with the previous report [47]. The absence of a PdH decomposition peak for 0.2Pd/TiO2 may be due to the low content of Pd-Pd structures. According to the recent report, the 2D or 3D Pd structure can be determined based on the hydrogen stoichiometry of β-PdH in TPR results [47]. The estimated amount of bulk Pd capable of forming β-PdH (3D Pd) on 0.2Pd/TiO2 and 5Pd/TiO2 are respectively ∼0 and 86 % (see Table S5 for calculations). The absence of a 3D structure for 0.2Pd/TiO2 is consistent with the HRTEM, CO DRIFTS and XPS results. Since H2 adsorption/dissociation abilities play a crucial role in hydrogenation reactions, H2-TPD measurements were conducted to analyze the hydrogen species formed on 0.2Pd/TiO2 and 5Pd/TiO2, and to understand their interactions with the catalysts (Fig. 3d). For 5Pd/TiO2, three groups of desorption peaks corresponding to the desorption of H2 on metallic Pd at −12.9, −0.8, and 78 °C, are observed. The peaks at −12.9 °C and −0.8 °C are attributed to hydrogen residing in subsurface Pd sites [48,49], while the 78 °C peak corresponds to PdH decomposition on the Pd surface. Desorption peaks above 200 °C are attributed to hydrogen species on TiO2, likely derived from hydrogen spillover [50]. These results are typical H2-TPD results for Pd NPs, further demonstrating 5Pd/TiO2 primarily consists of Pd NPs. In contrast, for 0.2Pd/TiO2, no desorption peaks corresponding to the desorption from the Pd surface are detected, and only the hydrogen species related to hydrogen spillover are observed. These findings align with the recently reported Pd1/TiO2 catalyst [51]. In comparison with 0.2Pd/TiO2, the ability of 5Pd/TiO2 to recombine the atomic hydrogen and hydrogen desorption below 0 °C suggest that the Pd sites on 5Pd/TiO2 have significantly higher hydrogen activation ability than those on 0.2Pd/TiO2. This may be attributed to the much lower content of Pd-Pd ensembles in 0.2Pd/TiO2 [52]. H2–D2 exchange reaction was performed to further assess the activation of molecular hydrogen on Pd/TiO2 catalysts. Under identical conditions and normalized by total Pd content, 0.2Pd/TiO2 and 5Pd/TiO2 afforded H2 conversions of 71.9 % and 38.8 %, respectively (Fig. 3e and Fig. S7), suggesting 0.2Pd/TiO2 has a higher overall H2 activation ability than 5Pd/TiO2. A simple alkene hydrogenation reaction can also be used as a probe to evaluate H2 activation [20,53]. Thus, styrene hydrogenation to ethylbenzene was conducted, and in this reaction, the conversion of ∼15 % was maintained by adjusting the reaction time to calculate the TOF (Fig. 3f). 0.2Pd/TiO2 exhibited higher activity than 5Pd/TiO2, as revealed by the apparent TOFs normalized by total Pd content (22.2 vs. 13.2 × 103 h−1), which is consistent with the H2-D2 exchange result. The superior overall H2 activation ability of 0.2Pd/TiO2 is primarily attributed to the highly dispersed Pd in 0.2Pd/TiO2, which results from the abundance of SACs and fully exposed NCs, though SACs have lower H2 activation ability compared to NPs [23,54,55]. 3.3 Kinetic studies Fig. 4 a–c present the kinetic curves for the total FAL hydrogenation on 0.2Pd/TiO2 and 5Pd/TiO2 using EtOH as the solvent. Due to the high activity of Pd/TiO2-catalyzed FAL hydrogenation in EtOH, the S/C ratio was fixed at 1000 to facilitate better sampling and analysis of the reaction. As shown in Fig. 4a, the FAL conversion on 0.2Pd/TiO2 steadily increased with reaction time, reaching approximately 80 % at 30 min, and then practically leveled off until the reaction ended at 90 min. This phenomenon is likely due to the strong adsorption of the substrate or its intermediates on the active sites during the reaction process. Similar results were also observed in the cases of FAL hydrogenation on Pd and Ni NPs [14,56]. For 5Pd/TiO2, the reaction proceeded much slower than 0.2 Pd/TiO2, and after 90 min, the FAL conversion was 54 % under identical conditions. Regarding the selectivity of FAL hydrogenation on 0.2Pd/TiO2 in EtOH, the main product was FOL in the initial stages (Fig. 4b). As the reaction progressed, the content of FOL decreased while the THFOL content increased, along with a slight increase in the by-products. These observations suggest that the predominant reaction pathway on Pd/TiO2 involves sequential hydrogenation of the furanic CO and furan ring of FAL, consistent with the literature reports [14]. At 90 min, the THFOL yield was 61 % for 0.2Pd/TiO2, and the by-products mainly included 2-methylfuran/2-methyltetrahydrofuran and the ring-opening compounds. For 5Pd/TiO2, the selectivity towards FOL was 92 % within the first 3 min, after which its content decreased and the by products increased over time (Fig. 4c). Unlike 0.2Pd/TiO2, the main by-products were acetals. At the end of the reaction, no THFOL product and almost only acetals were obtained for 5Pd/TiO2. This may be due to the lower hydrogenation activity of 5Pd/TiO2. The above results suggested that the FAL hydrogenation on 0.2Pd/TiO2 predominantly occurs, whereas for the case of 5Pd/TiO2, acid catalysis is more prevalent. The different product selectivity is thus likely attributed to the presence of different active sites on the two catalysts as demonstrated above. The kinetic curves of Pd/TiO2 catalysts were also investigated in 55 %EtOH (Fig. 4d–f). In comparison with the EtOH system, the catalytic activity of 0.2Pd/TiO2 decreased significantly when 45 %H2O was added. Thus, the S/C ratio was adjusted from 1000 to 300 to better reflect the catalytic results in the binary solvent system. In the mixed solvent, for 0.2Pd/TiO2, the FAL conversion reached ∼80 % at 15 min and almost remained constant when further prolonging the reaction time (Fig. 4d), similar with the results observed in EtOH. Compared to 0.2Pd/TiO2, 5Pd/TiO2 displayed a slightly lower initial FAL conversion but a much higher final FAL conversion of 95 %. The corresponding product distribution of FAL hydrogenation in 55 %EtOH are shown in Fig. 4e and f. For the case of 0.2Pd/TiO2, FAL was first converted to FOL and acetals at initial 3 min, and the acetals quickly disappeared as the reaction proceeded (Fig. 4e). This result indicates that there are two parallel reaction pathways on 0.2Pd/TiO2 at the beginning of the reaction, that is, the hydrogenation of FAL to FOL and subsequently to THFOL being the main reaction path. The rapid decrease of acetal content may be due to the reversible nature of acid-catalysed condensation reaction. Consequently, THFOL selectivity reached ∼100 % at 60 min, much higher than that in EtOH. A similar product distribution and reaction trend was observed for 5Pd/TiO2, although the magnitude of product distribution changes was smaller (Fig. 4f). Interestingly, H2O totally altered the reaction route from acid catalysis in EtOH to hydrogenation in 55 %EtOH on 5Pd/TiO2, suggesting the promotion effect of H2O in FAL hydrogenation. It is thus concluded that the main reaction route both on the two catalysts are FAL hydrogenation. The inability of FOL to further transform into THFOL on 5Pd/TiO2 may be due to its low Pd dispersion and thus, resulting in a low availability of active sites for the subsequent hydrogenation. According to the Sabatier principle [57,58], the electronic structure of metal surface is directly associated with the adsorption strength of reactants/intermediates, which significantly affects the catalytic performance. Reaction kinetics is a powerful probe to characterize the surface electronic structure of metal NPs, as it is very sensitive to the structure of active sites [53,59]. First, the system in this investigation was verified to be free of mass transfer resistance to ensure the obtained kinetic data within the kinetic region (Experimental Section and SI) [20,35]. Given that hydrogenation is the main reaction route in 55 %EtOH, the reaction orders of 0.2Pd/TiO2 and 5Pd/TiO2 with respect to H2 and FAL were investigated in the mixed solvent (Fig. 5 a and b). The positive reaction orders with respect to H2 on 0.2Pd/TiO2 and 5Pd/TiO2 were 0.91 and 1.13, respectively. In heterogeneous catalysis, the reaction order reflects how the surface concentration of adsorbed reactant species affects the reaction rate. The near-first-order dependence on H2 for FAL hydrogenation over Pd/TiO2 suggests that the adsorbed hydrogen species are far from the Sabatier optimum (Fig. S8) [59], indicating low surface coverage of hydrogen species on the Pd surface. Based on the dual-site Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism, the near-first-order in H2 at low H2 pressure suggests the second hydrogenation of CO is the RDS (Eq. S15). Previous kinetic studies [32] and DFT calculations [60] have shown that sequential hydrogenation of the O atom, followed by the C atom in the carbonyl group, has a much lower free energy barrier than the reverse sequence. The almost first-order reaction with respect to H2 for both on 0.2Pd/TiO2 and 5Pd/TiO2 indicate that, for both catalysts, the RDS is the hydrogenation of C atom in the CO group of FAL [32]. These results show that FAL hydrogenation on both 0.2Pd/TiO2 and 5Pd/TiO2 follows the same reaction pathway with a similar RDS. The reaction order towards FAL on 0.2Pd/TiO2 is −0.55 (Fig. 5b). The negative value means that FAL acts as a “poison” for Pd NPs, due to the strong adsorption of the substrate or its hydrogenation intermediates on the Pd active sites. This strong adsorption of FAL also renders the desorption of the reactants difficult (Fig. S8). This result is consistent with the time/conversion curve shown in Fig. 4d, in which a plateau is observed after the FAL conversion exceeded 80 %. The reaction order towards FAL on 5Pd/TiO2 is −1.33, whereas the value for 0.2Pd/TiO2 is closer to 0, indicating relatively weaker adsorption of FAL on 0.2Pd/TiO2. Given the distinct active sites on the two catalysts, as demonstrated above, these findings may suggest that the active sites for FAL/FOL activation on 0.2Pd/TiO2 differ from those on 5Pd/TiO2. It is possible that activation occurs primarily on the SACs [54,61–63]. Previous studies have shown that Pd SACs are more effective at activating the CO group, while Pd NPs are better at activating H2 [23]. Therefore, the unique ability of SACs on 0.2Pd/TiO2 to activate FAL/FOL, combined with the high H2 activation capacity of Pd NCs in H2 [55] and the spillover effect promoted by protic solvents (e.g., water, alcohols) [64,65] contribute to the significantly higher yield of THFOL. Based on the above results, the high catalytic performance of 0.2Pd/TiO2 in total FAL hydrogenation can be attributed primarily to the synergistic effect of Pd SACs and Pd NCs, which could activate FAL/FOL and H2, respectively. Additionally, the promotion of hydrogenation by H2O—either through hydrogen bond-enhanced substrate activation or improved H2 activation [32,33] —leads to higher hydrogenation selectivity, even through H2O may block some active sites. The apparent activation energies calculated for FAL hydrogenation to FOL on 0.2Pd/TiO2 and 5Pd/TiO2 are 52.9 and 50.4 kJ/mol (Fig. 5c), respectively. These nearly identical values suggest that both the catalysts possess “similar active sites” for FAL hydrogenation in the presence of H2O [66], despite potential differences in their active site interfaces, as evidenced by the above characterizations. 3.4 Recycle stability and substrate scope The recyclability of 0.2Pd/TiO2 was tested using FAL hydrogenation as a model reaction. After the first reaction cycle, the liquid was decanted after centrifugation of the reaction mixture. The obtained catalyst was thoroughly washed with EtOH and then used directly for the next run. Notably, 0.2Pd/TiO2 retained its catalytic performance over seven consecutive recycling runs without significant loss of activity or selectivity (Fig. 5d), demonstrating its exceptional stability. Furthermore, under low FAL conversion conditions, the catalyst maintained stability through five additional cycles (Fig. S9a), further corroborating its robustness. It is noted that 0.2Pd/TiO2 could be recycled 7 times without any obvious loss of activity and selectivity (Fig. 5d), implying the excellent stability of 0.2Pd/TiO2. Similar recycle stability results were obtained for the 5Pd/TiO2 (Fig. S9b). These results also suggest that the deactivation phenomenon for FAL hydrogenation of Pd/TiO2 catalysts, as shown in Fig. 4a and d, is temporary, which results from the relatively strong adsorption of the reactants or intermediates on the active sites. Given the excellent catalytic performance of 0.2Pd/TiO2 for the total hydrogenation of FAL to THFOL, we further expanded the substrate scope to other biobased furanic compounds. As shown in Table 2 , 0.2Pd/TiO2 could effectively catalyze the hydrogenation of various furan-based compounds. The hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfural (HMF), one of the most important C6 platform chemicals from cellulosic biomass, yielded the industrially relevant chemical 2,5-dihydroxymethyltetrahydrofuran in 64 % yield (Table 2, Entry 1). Under identical conditions, 2,5-furandimethanol was fully hydrogenated to 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl) tetrahydrofuran in 80 % yield (Table 2, Entry 2). For benzofuran, methyl 2-furoate, 5-methoxybenzofuran, and methyl 6-benzofurancarboxylate, the corresponding furan ring saturated products were also obtained in high yields of 99 % (Table 2, Entries 3–6). For 2-methylfuran and dimethyl furan-2,5-dicarboxylate, the S/C ratio was adjusted from 200 to 50 to increase the furan-ring hydrogenated products. After 6 h, the respective furan ring-hydrogenated products were obtained in 89 % and 77 % yields. These results demonstrate that 0.2Pd/TiO2 is a highly efficient catalyst for the total hydrogenation of bio-based furan derivatives across a broad substrate scope. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have developed a highly active TiO2-supported Pd catalyst possessing SACs and NCs on the support for the total hydrogenation of FAL to THFOL. Under mild conditions, 0.2Pd/TiO2 with a relatively low Pd content (0.2 wt%) could achieve 90 % FAL conversion and 96 % selectivity to THFOL, outperforming both conventional high-Pd-content catalysts (5 wt%) and most of the reported catalysts. Detailed characterization and kinetic studies suggest that the superior catalytic performance of 0.2Pd/TiO2 is due to the synergistic effect of Pd SACs and NCs, which could activate FAL/FOL and H2, respectively, as well as the promoting effect of H2O in the total hydrogenation process. Moreover, 0.2Pd/TiO2 could recycle 7 times without any obvious activity and selectivity decreases in FAL hydrogenation and could also effectively catalyse the hydrogenation of various other bio-based furanic derivatives. This work provides valuable insights for the rational design of cascade catalysts to enhance tandem hydrogenation efficiency. coredata.dc:description: Total furfural (FAL) hydrogenation to the industrially valuable tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFOL) involves the cascade hydrogenation of the formyl and furanic groups. However, supported metal catalysts are generally confronted with low activity, especially under mild conditions. Herein, we present a highly active Pd catalyst supported on TiO2 with a Pd loading of 0.2 wt% (0.2Pd/TiO2) for the efficient one-pot conversion of FAL to THFOL. Under mild conditions (25 °C, 60 bar H2), 0.2Pd/TiO2 achieves 90 % FAL conversion and 96 % selectivity to THFOL, outperforming the conventional high-Pd-content catalysts (e.g. 5 wt%Pd/TiO2) and most reported catalysts. Detailed characterization and kinetic investigations reveal that the exceptional performance stems from the synergistic interplay between Pd single atoms and nanoclusters on the 0.2Pd/TiO2 catalyst. Furthermore, kinetic studies highlight the crucial role of H2O in promoting the desired reaction pathway. Impressively, 0.2Pd/TiO2 demonstrates excellent stability, the activity and selectivity remain nearly identical even over seven consecutive reaction cycles. Moreover, the catalyst exhibits broad applicability, effectively hydrogenating various furanic compounds to the corresponding saturated products. This study provides key insights into the rational design of highly efficient and selective catalysts for tandem hydrogenation reactions.
